slos.gt_text:
Learning Objectives:
Students should develop understanding of main goals of digital forensics, which include
identifying and preserving digital evidence, conducting in-depth data analysis using forensic
tools, documenting findings, and presenting them in a detailed comprehensive manner. It also
involves understanding the principles of computer and network systems, data storage, and
developing critical thinking and communication skills to build a narrative of events from digital
artifacts.

details.filename: Exploring NH Forests, Drawing to Discover the Tree Community.pdf

slos.gt_text:
Student Learning Outcomes
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
● Understand and appreciate art and its historical role in observational science
● Demonstrate foundational drawing skills such as line, value, form, perspective and composition
● Identify common New Hampshire tree species and their roles within forest communities
● Apply and explain the ecological principles that govern forest dynamics, including species
interactions, succession and forest biodiversity
● Produce a written and illustrated report that integrates ecological research, field observations

Learning Objectives
Analyze security intelligence frameworks; Evaluate policy implications; Apply analytic tools to case studies
slos.pred_text:
Learning Objectives
Students that successfully complete this course will be able to:
• Understand the role of the analyst in the intelligence cycle.
• Understand the relationship between analysis and synthesis; and relate logic and
critical thinking to intelligence analysis.
NSIA 820 / NSIA 720
Intelligence Analysis
UPDATED 05/07/2025
Instructor
John Borek, Ph.D.

workload.gt: expected to spend at least 16 hours per week on this class

slos.gt_text:
Learning Objectives
Develop strategic analysis skills; Communicate intelligence findings; Apply quantitative methods in national security
slos.pred_text:
Learning Objectives
Students that successfully complete this course will be able to:
• Distinguish among the core elements of the intelligence enterprise (collection, analysis,
operations) as they relate to national security.
• Assess the applicability of intelligence assets in support of national security objectives.
• Understand the role of intelligence as a component of whole of government efforts in
support of national security objectives.
• Evaluate the conduct of intelligence activities.
• Design a plan for intelligence in support of national security policies.

slos.gt_text:
Learning Objectives
Identify common technological and organizational measures for cybersecurity (focus: detection concepts and organizational relationships); Explain and give examples of the roles of best practices and standards in the design and implementation of such security measures; Explain the functional and organizational advantages and disadvantages of these measures, including impacts from their interaction; Assess the limitations of these security measures in the contexts of organizational change and dynamic threats, flawed technology, and flawed organizational policies and practices; Translate lessons learned from incidents into recommendations for cybersecurity planning and preparedness for better detection.
slos.pred_text:
Learning Outcomes
With successful completion of this course, students are able to:
• Identify common technological and organizational measures for cybersecurity (focus:
detection concepts and organizational relationships).
• Explain and give examples of the roles of best practices and standards in the design and
implementation of such security measures.
• Explain the functional and organizational advantages and disadvantages of these
measures, including impacts from their interaction.
• Assess the limitations of these security measures in the contexts of organizational change

Situate cybersecurity incident response and investigation within an organization's overall incident response policies and processes; Identify rules and best practices for reporting or otherwise communicating information about cybersecurity events and incidents; Identify concepts and methods for effective containment and mitigation of cybersecurity incidents; Articulate the roles of common tools and techniques for investigating and analyzing cybersecurity incidents; Explain and give examples of the differing mandates and priorities in the communities of interest for incident response and investigation (e.g., CERTs and CSIRTs, law enforcement agencies, regulators, vendors, intelligence community, etc.).

slos.gt_text:
Learning Objectives
Analyze the intelligence cycle, recognize sources and methods and explain how intelligence contributes to U.S. national/homeland security; Demonstrate knowledge of contemporary or emergent threats, challenges or issues; Recognize and define terrorism, its origins, ideologies, and goals; Define national and homeland security intelligence; Describe the role and structure of the American intelligence community; Identify and describe the steps in a traditional intelligence cycle model
slos.pred_text:
Learning Objectives
Define national and homeland security intelligence.
Describe the role and structure of the American intelligence community.
Identify and describe the steps in a traditional intelligence cycle model.
Critique the intelligence cycle as a model for understanding intelligence activity.
Evaluate national security threats and place them on a threat continuum.
Define, describe, and provide examples of strategic intelligence, warning intelligence, oversight, collection, analysis, covert action, and counterintelligence.

Students should develop understanding of main goals of digital forensics, which include
identifying and preserving digital evidence, conducting in-depth data analysis using forensic
tools, documenting findings, and presenting them in a detailed comprehensive manner. It also
involves understanding the principles of computer and network systems, data storage, and
developing critical thinking and communication skills to build a narrative of events from digital
artifacts.

slos.pred_text:
Learning Objectives:
Students develop understanding of modern internet, the world wide web, and how a web browser
bridges that divide. Students will develop skills in building web pages using HTML that can both
display information and gather input from users. Students will also learn to control and modify
web pages with JavaScript
Software Tools:
We will use a text editor and a web browser which most modern operating systems provide or

slos.pred_text:
Learning Outcomes:
Understand the principles of effective data visualization.
Create visually appealing and informative charts, graphs, and dashboards.
Use data visualization tools and software to present data in an engaging way.
Apply storytelling techniques to communicate data insights effectively.
Critically evaluate the effectiveness of different visualizations and provide constructive feedback.
Course Resources:
Other Class Materials:
YouTube, LinkedIn, and other search engines will be helpful in this course.

Description of Course Activities and Requirements:
Grading Percentages:
Course Schedule & Topics:
All assignments are due Sunday by 11:59 pm.
For each day that the assignment is late there will be a 10% deduction up to 7 days.  After 7 days the assignment will not be accepted and a zero will be recorded.

slos.pred_text:
Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this course, students will be able to:
Select appropriate visualization techniques for different data and business contexts.
Apply design principles (preattentive attributes, Gestalt, data-ink ratio, color theory).
Perform basic data mining tasks (classification, clustering, association, prediction).
Use MS Excel, and MS Power BI for data preparation, visualization, and dashboards.
Explore and explain data with visual storytelling.
Evaluate visualizations and models for ethical and accurate insights.

slos.pred_text:
Learning Outcomes:
(1) To enhance your capacity to evaluate, ethically and legally, problematic IT
scenarios and to develop rational responses to such scenarios.
(2) To enhance your critical thinking and writing skills, especially regarding exercising ethical leadership in an IT environment.
(3) To apply specific ethical theory to business and societal scenarios to solve ethical situations.
(4) To learn how to manage IT operations in an organization with integrity.
Canvas Application: students should access the modules portion of Canvas to find materials for the specific class sessions (which should be consumed “before” the class). Further, you will submit all written assignments via the upload icon for the applicable week’s module on Canvas (DO NOT send the assignment to the professor’s email). Assignments will be returned via your Canvas account once they are graded (within 42 hours).

slos.pred_text:
Learning Objectives
Computers are embedded in everything these days. By the end of the class you should feel confident taking a powerful single board computer and connecting/programming it to perform specific tasks. Programs in this class are written in Python. If you haven't seen it before it's pretty easy to learn. If you have seen it, you will hopefully get better with it. Just about every computer system has some sort of way to input data and see results. You will become more comfortable attaching these kinds of devices.

final_grade_scale.pred:
Your final grade is calculated as follows:
Labs (25%)
Homework (25%)
Independent homework assignments are given and collected on a weekly basis. Unless specifically stated, the major portion of the course work will be done using a browser and a text editor. The homework is designed to build your understanding of the class topics and use of the Internet and to develop your coding ability, e.g., in HTML and CSS. Topics from the homework will be used in class activities, exams, and the final project so it is important to complete the material with accuracy and understanding. Each assignment is due at the date and time listed. It is your responsibility to allow enough time during the week to complete the activities despite obstacles (technology driven or personal) that may arise. Late work is anything submitted after the announced due date and time. You will lose 10% per day for work submitted late for up to 48 hours after the due day. Submissions must be completed through MyCourses in order to receive credits.
Final Web Project (25%)
Participation (10%)
